Karl Wright wrote:

> On Heritrix 1.5, doing an extended crawl, we begin to see errors that
> look like the I/O system is getting confused.  These occur occasionally
> at first, then with greater frequency.  Here's a few of them:
>
>
> 11/09/2005 02:47:42 +0000 SEVERE org.archive.util.FileUtils copyFile
> Failed copy, trying workaround: Copying
> /usr/share/heritrix/src/jobs/NZ8-20051107193326172/order.xml to
> /usr/share/heritrix/src/jobs/NZ8-20051107193326172/order_20051108135026.xml 
>
> with extent 11012 got IOE: Invalid argument

The message should be better -- should be a WARNING -- but whats 
happening here is that workaround code for a 2.6 kernel bug is being 
triggered; The copy likely succeeded (Check heritrix_out.log subseqent 
to the above SEVERE to be sure).  Here is pointer to the workaround 
code: 
http://crawler.archive.org/xref/org/archive/util/FileUtils.html#272. 
Follow the cited link to learn more.

>
>
> 11/09/2005 20:02:19 +0000 SEVERE org.archive.crawler.fetcher.FetchHTTP
> innerProcess
> http://www.stephensmithenergy.com/PXD_CompanyOutlookReport_7154_FINAL.pdf
> RIS still open. Should have been closed by method release: ToeThread
> #345:
> http://www.stephensmithenergy.com/PXD_CompanyOutlookReport_7154_FINAL.pdf
> 11/09/2005 20:10:52 +0000 SEVERE org.archive.crawler.fetcher.FetchHTTP
> innerProcess
> http://www.stephensmithenergy.com/MonthlyEnergyOutlook_6194_FINAL.pdf
> RIS still open. Should have been closed by method release: ToeThread
> #326: 
> http://www.stephensmithenergy.com/MonthlyEnergyOutlook_6194_FINAL.pdf
>
> I looked at the code where the latter error is generated, and can only
> conclude that a file close operation is throwing an IOException, which
> is interfering with the file being actually marked closed.  I've further
> confirmed that there is no chance we are out of disk space, or anything
> mundane like that.

Whats your version of Heritrix?  Is it HEAD?  If so, from what date 
(JVM, and OS would help too).  Above may have been fixed (See 
http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?group_id=73833&atid=539099&func=detail&aid=1090916).


>
> Is it possible that we have a race condition here?  What is the Heritrix
> thread model where ReplayInputStream's are concerned?  If you have a
> writer that gets a ReplayInputStream from the curi and uses it (which we
> do), is there a chance of interaction with the FetchHTTP stuff?
>
General model is that a single thread does processing of a CrawlURI from 
start to finish and but for a few important exceptions -- such as the 
Frontier -- processors like the FetchHTTP processor are not shared 
amongst threads; there's an instance per crawl URI being processed. 
Files written to disk carry the thread number as suffix so shouldn't be 
contention between threads over files: e.g. the files backing 
RecordingInput/OutputStreams.  Here's a pertinent section from the dev. 
manual: http://crawler.archive.org/articles/developer_manual.html#N104CA.

Yours,
St.Ack

>
> Thanks,
> Karl
